entry.title: LeetCode 78. Subsets
entry.content:
Given a set of distinct integers, nums, return all possible subsets (the power set).

Note: The solution set must not contain duplicate subsets.

Example:

Then I found a more concise version:

entry.title: LeetCode 791. Custom Sort String
entry.content:
S and T are strings composed of lowercase letters. In S, no letter occurs more than once.

S was sorted in some custom order previously. We want to permute the characters of T so that they match the order that S was sorted. More specifically, if x occurs before y in S, then x should occur before y in the returned string.

Return any permutation of T (as a string) that satisfies this property.

Note:

  • S has length at most 26, and no character is repeated in S.
  • T has length at most 200.
  • S and T consist of lowercase letters only.

Well there is the no loop no set solution :

First my program was like this and it failed :

The failed case is :

Input

"disqyr" "iwyrysqrdj"

Output

"disqyyrrw,j"

Expected

"disqyyrrjw"

So I wrote a testing program :

Now it's clear that the rest of second array needs to be turned into a string.

And Three dots ( â€¦ ) in JavaScript occurs in a function call or alike, it's called a "spread operator" and expands an array into a list.
entry.summary: S and T are strings composed of lowercase letters. In S, no letter occurs more than o

entry.title: LeetCode 33. Search in Rotated Sorted Array
entry.content:
Suppose an array sorted in ascending order is rotated at some pivot unknown to you beforehand.

(i.e., [0,1,2,4,5,6,7] might become [4,5,6,7,0,1,2]).

You are given a target value to search. If found in the array return its index, otherwise return -1.

You may assume no duplicate exists in the array.

Your algorithm's runtime complexity must be in the order of O(log n).

Example 1:

Example 2:

Well it already says O(log n) so we must take divide and conquer into consideration .
entry.summary:
Suppose an array sorted in ascending order is rotated at some pivot unknown to you beforehand.

(i.e., [0,1,2,4,

entry.title: 2020.4.4 How Chinese websites become balck and white
entry.content:
If you don't see any images pls wait a sec cuz I use root-relative Link to store images. It might take a while to load.

As a heavy Douban user, I checked Douban web ver first.

I was doing an all-nighter and boom , the world turned colorless.

One of my friends told me that use document.body.classList.remove('gray-mode') can reignite the original view. I tried and it worked !

So I opened my Firefox dev tools and looked into the code.

It quite clear that the gray-mode class in the body works the magic here.

Basically there are three method , all filters.

But when I refresh the page , the original view still sneaks in first for about half a sec so It's not perfect.

Also I searched for "grayscale website solutions" and found this on Stackoverflow

It suggests :
entry.summary: If you don't see any images pls wait a sec cuz I use root-relative Link to store images. It might take a while to load.

entry.title: LeetCode 128. Longest Consecutive Sequence
entry.content:
Given an unsorted array of integers, find the length of the longest consecutive elements sequence.

Your algorithm should run in O(n) complexity.

Example:

Use hash map to decrease the time complexity.

Strictly speaking , It's not exactly O(n) ...

entry.content:
Given a string s, find the longest palindromic substring in s. You may assume that the maximum length of s is 1000.

Example 1:

Example 2:

    The index of the first character to exclude from the returned substring.

entry.title: LeetCode 105. Construct Binary Tree from Preorder and Inorder Traversal
entry.content:
\105. Construct Binary Tree from Preorder and Inorder Traversal

Medium

Given preorder and inorder traversal of a tree, construct the binary tree.

Note: You may assume that duplicates do not exist in the tree.

For example, given

Return the following binary tree:

The shift() method removes the first element from an array and returns that removed element.

Use recursive method to build binary trees.

Recall how we build the tree from preorder & inorder info

First step : find the position of the first element from the preorder list in the inorder list

3 | 9 | 20 15 7

9 | 3 | 15 20 7

Then it shows that the root is 3 , left tree is [9] , right tree is [20,15,7]

So step into the recursion ...

\105. Construct Binary Tree from Preorder and Inorder Traversal

Medium

entry.title: 820. Short Encoding of Words
entry.content:
Given a list of words, we may encode it by writing a reference string S and a list of indexes A.

For example, if the list of words is ["time", "me", "bell"], we can write it as S = "time#bell#" and indexes = [0, 2, 5].

Then for each index, we will recover the word by reading from the reference string from that index until we reach a "#" character.

What is the length of the shortest reference string S possible that encodes the given words?

Example:

Note:

  1. 1 <= words.length <= 2000.
  2. 1 <= words[i].length <= 7.
  3. Each word has only lowercase letters.

An intuitive brute force solution : remove shorter words

Use arrayObject.slice(start,end) to get certain slice of a string

Simply remove the shorter words from the original list.

Though it's basically a O(n^2) method , the ranking score is pretty good ðŸ¤”

Trie method

Sort the Strings based on their length in the descending order

The charCodeAt() method returns an integer between 0 and 65535 representing the UTF-16 code unit at the given index.

Trie is why type something into a search engine and it will show a list of related words !
entry.summary: Given a list of words, we may encode it by writing a reference string S and a list of indexes A.

entry.title: LeetCode 31. Next Permutation
entry.content:
Implement next permutation, which rearranges numbers into the lexicographically next greater permutation of numbers.

If such arrangement is not possible, it must rearrange it as the lowest possible order (ie, sorted in ascending order).

The replacement must be in-place and use only constant extra memory.

Here are some examples. Inputs are in the left-hand column and its corresponding outputs are in the right-hand column.

entry.title: Puzzle | Set 35 (2 Eggs and 100 Floors) && Egg Dropping Puzzle | DP-11
entry.content:
The following is a description of the instance of this famous puzzle involving 2 eggs and a building with 100 floors.

Suppose that we wish to know which stories in a 100-story building are safe to drop eggs from, and which will cause the eggs to break on landing. What strategy should be used to drop eggs such that total number of drops in worst case is minimized and we find the required floor.

We may make a few assumptions:

  • An egg that survives a fall can be used again.
  • A broken egg must be discarded.
  • The effect of a fall is the same for all eggs.
  • If an egg breaks when dropped, then it would break if dropped from a higher floor.
  • If an egg survives a fall then it would survive a shorter fall.

ç»å…¸çš„ðŸ¶å®¶é¢è¯•é¢˜

1) If the egg breaks after dropping from xth floor, then we only need to check for floors lower than x with remaining eggs; so the problem reduces to x-1 floors and n-1 eggs
2) If the egg doesnâ€™t break after dropping from the xth floor, then we only need to check for floors higher than x; so the problem reduces to k-x floors and n eggs.

entry.summary: The following is a description of the instance of this famous puzzle involving 2 eggs and a building with 100 floors.

entry.title: LeetCode 338. Counting Bits
entry.content:
Given a non negative integer number num. For every numbers i in the range 0 â‰¤ i â‰¤ num calculate the number of 1â€™s in their binary representation and return them as an array.

Example 1:

Example 2:

Follow up:

  • It is very easy to come up with a solution with run time O(n*sizeof(integer)). But can you do it in linear time O(n) /possibly in a single pass?
  • Space complexity should be O(n).
  • Can you do it like a boss? Do it without using any builtin function like __builtin_popcount in c++ or in any other language.

entry.title: LeetCode 705. Design HashSet
entry.content:
Design a HashSet without using any built-in hash table libraries.

To be specific, your design should include these functions:

  • add(value): Insert a value into the HashSet.
  • contains(value) : Return whether the value exists in the HashSet or not.
  • remove(value): Remove a value in the HashSet. If the value does not exist in the HashSet, do nothing.

Example:

Note:

  • All values will be in the range of [0, 1000000].
  • The number of operations will be in the range of [1, 10000].
  • Please do not use the built-in HashSet library.

entry.title: LeetCode 101. Symmetric Tree
entry.content:
Given a binary tree, check whether it is a mirror of itself (ie, symmetric around its center).

For example, this binary tree [1,2,2,3,4,4,3] is symmetric:

But the following [1,2,2,null,3,null,3] is not:

entry.title: LeetCode 20. Valid Parentheses
entry.content:
Given a string containing just the characters '(', ')', '{', '}', '[' and ']', determine if the input string is valid.

An input string is valid if:

  1. Open brackets must be closed by the same type of brackets.
  2. Open brackets must be closed in the correct order.

Note that an empty string is also considered valid.

Example 1:

Example 2:

Example 3:

Example 4:

Example 5:
